Subject: Assessment
Body:
Courtney Stonestreet (Transition Counselor)/Pittsburgh Public Schools

I think it is important to first gather information from the student and parent to see what their goals and plans are for after graduation. This is something you want to do often so that you can see if their answers differ from year to year. After that utilizing assessments to see if their interests and skills align with what they are reporting they want to do. Subject: Trina Knauff, Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: Transition assessments must be thoughtfully selected based on student preferences, future plans, and dreams in addition to the existing academic, functional, and transition data we presently have for the student. Using the “Assessment Connection Grid” can help us identify what gaps of post-secondary, employment, and independent living information are we missing that is necessary to drive post-secondary measurable annual goals relating to transition? We can help identify what assessments would be appropriate based on these gaps of information in correlation with what the student wants to achieve after high school. Are results valued? This is a pivotal question that is oftentimes missed in the process. An assessment completed without review and application of the results to the existing transition plan then serves no point. It’s essential to view the transition assessment process not one that occurs one time per year prior to the annual IEP meeting, but an ongoing process that each step is based off of the previous results. Oftentimes school districts will administer the same formal assessments every year without valuing and applying the data to the transition plan, future assessments, goals, services, and activities. Ongoing transition planning meetings should occur, and data should be shared upon completion of each assessment. Action steps should be decided upon reviewing the results of each assessment to continue to progress toward the students’ transition goals. Courses, services, and/or activities may need to be revised based on what the new data reveals.

Subject: Kristen Lovett-Abington Heights High School - Shivock
Body:
Formal transition based assessments need to be in conjunction with less formal levels of assessment. Teachers responsible for transition planning need to have a strong rapport with their students and their families, and have the ability to have open and continuous conversations with them in order to determine their individualized post secondary goals. 

Teenagers' goals are always changing as they grow, develop academically/emotionally ,and as they gain more exposure to potential post secondary options. A continuum of planned transition activities that build on each other over the course of many years will help students develop this ongoing exposure. 

Transition planning should be discussed at all IEP meetings after the student turns 14. Parents should be reminded consistently that this transition component is contained within their child's IEP, and they should be informed of community based supports that can help them and their child plan for the future as a family-unit.

Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kimberly Dorus-Quaker Valley High School (Mike Lewis-LEA)
Body: To ensure that the student’s transition assessments produce MPSGs that align with their personal preferences and plans, there are both formal and informal transition assessments that can be utilized.   Informal assessments an include observations, interviews and teacher reporting.  Formal assessments may include interest inventories and skill assessments.  There is no single assessment that should be used for all students.  The assessments need to be appropriate for that student.  There should be open lines of communication between the family and the school.  The most essential participants in this process are the parents and the student, but input from teachers and outside agencies can also be helpful.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jami Smith-Executive Education Academy Charter School-Sarah Evans(LEA)
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Noel Skorvan, SAEC
The team needs to look at where the student is presently, where the student is going and how to help the student get there.  There should be a variety of transition assessments administered in order to develop a plan that can be successful in meeting the student's interest, abilities and prepare the student for their future.    Provide the student with a balance of informal and formal transition assessments to gain a variety of information.   The parents involvement along with the entire team is critical to developing an affective transition plan.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Abigail Bator - Quaker Valley School District (High School)
Body:
To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that align with their preferences, plans, and dreams, varied transition assessments, both formal and informal, must be utilized.  These assessments are necessary to gauge student interest and readiness for the future.

To include and support students and parents/family members in the transition assessment process, the school must keep the lines of communication open throughout the entire process.  This should not be something that is discussed only that the annual IEP meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Christa Fisher- AHCCS
Body:
In order to ensure that transition assessments produce MAGs it is important that those assessments are current, within the calendar year and also that there is a variety of assessments conducted, both formal and informal. This coupled with previous documentation allows for the team to get an accurate idea of the student's PINS and goal plan with those in mind. 

It is important to engage the family as well as the student each year in the transition process. I send out a survey to the parent and complete an informal interview with each student before the meeting. We further discuss their transition goals as a team at the meeting and I utilize that to support goal and SDI decisions so that the family feels their voice and input is heard.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michael Routh, Elizabeth Forward
Body: The team has to make sure it has student voice at the center of the planning. We should ensure that students complete age-appropriate assessments related to education, training, employment, and living/life skills.  As other folks have said, we need a mix of formal and informal assessments that inform the team. It's critical.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lauryn Filipkoski, Abington Heights High School
Body: It is important to continuously collect meaningful data in regards to student’s interest, needs and interests.  Data should be collected formally and informally.  Having open communication with parents and involving them in the planning process will help keep them engaged and informed in their student’s interests.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Annakaye Fenell-Northwestern School District (Kristen Rutkowski-LEA)
Body: As a student participates in their own education and transition planning, their future plans and dreams could easily change. To ensure that a student’s transition plan produces measurable post-school goals, we must frequently provide opportunities for the students to complete formal and informal assessments that provide them examples of things they may be successful at once they graduate from high school. Also, by including parents and family members as well as other teachers or school personnel, they can provide valuable insight on different skills these students may possess in different areas of their education. These observations, interviews, and data collected can help guide transition goals and start the conversation on different field experiences or job shadowing the student could participate in in order to gain skills needed for after graduation.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Smith-Interboro School District
Body: Incorporating a variety of both informal and formal assessments is imperative for an accurate and comprehensive assessment. In order for a transition assessment to be successful, all team members must be involved in the evaluation and transition process. This will encourage carryover and monitoring of the on-going process when all members are involved. It is important to update and modify the student’s goals and progress in order to account for changes, various insights and preferences the student may note.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: William Friel Interboro School District
Body: There are many ways to ensure that MPSGs are aligned with student preferences. Informal and formal testing, accompanied with parental and student involvement lead to better planning. This process needs to be ongoing should student interest change over time.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Julie Miller, NWSD, Kristen Rutkowski
Body: In order to ensure transition assessments are aligned with student preferences, future plans, and dreams we have to make sure to reassess often. We can not assume that what a student said in 9th grade is the same as what they want when they are in 11th grade. We also need to keep information as accurate as possible. We should include the student, parent, and current teachers to have as many observations as possible--some people might see the student in a "different light" and may be able to give different ideas about the skills and/or needs of the student. If we us a combination of formal and informal assessments, the student will be better at assessing their skills, wants, needs, and how they want to progress through their HS setting and where they want to go after graduation.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nicole Talbert- Keystone Oaks high School
Body: By interviewing the student, parents, teachers and using more formal tests and surveys we can get a better understanding of where the student is and where they plan on going to create goals that help them meet these challenges. We can offer suggestions to the student, family, etc. to ensure the student chooses activities and coursework that helps them meet their goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jenna Bish - Northwestern School District
Body: In order to ensure successful transition for students, we must implement and utilize a variety of formal and informal assessments.  Student interviews provide a great deal of insight and are necessary when considering student preferences and interests.  Open communication between the IEP team and families/students is crucial in creating a successful transition plan. Student abilities, goals, needs, and skills must be considered and should drive the process of creating a transition plan.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sharon Mahoney Northwestern School District
Body: To ensure successful transition for the students we serve we need to implement a variety of transition surveys and assessments, taking into account the student abilities, needs, goals, and skills. This will provide accurate and complete data that will drive the process toward what the individual student needs to meet with success post high school.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Patrick Gaughan, Abington Heights High School
Body:
The best way to ensure that MPSGs are produced is to ask three questions during development. Where is the student currently, what are their goals, and how do we progress from where they are currently to their end goal. We can do that by a variety of formal and informal assessments that address the student's interests, strengths, areas of need, and skills.

The best way to include all stakeholders in transition planning is allowing them to have input in the process. I've seen this take place mostly during meetings when assessments and goals or being discussed for a student. The stakeholders take part in the conversation, offering ideas on how to best help a student to meet their goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Robert Kelly - Interboro School District
Body:
Data, data, and more data.  Without fully ascertaining the student's interests and cross-referencing this with information about the student's abilities, where they are right now, and parent input, we will not have sufficient MPSGs.  We need to collect data through formal and informal surveys and checklists and interviews with current and former staff, parents and , most importantly, the student.

The best way to include and support all stakeholders would be to keep them involved throughout the process.  Once decisions are made, treat them like draft statements and review/tweak them with the student and family.  Maintain contact through scheduled check-ins during progress monitoring times and treat these meetings, if necessary, like IEP amendment meetings to further tweak as needed.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kim Boswell- Interboro School District
Body: There are many ways to ensure that students transition assessments results in MPSGs and follow their hopes and dreams by early on implementing formal and informal assessments to ensure the alignment of goals and programming. It is also critical to involve the students family and get the parents input as they are a huge part of our IEP team.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kristy Johnson - Northwestern School District
Body: In order to ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams then we must utilize a variety of assessments including formal and informal. Information must be taken from all members of the IEP team including parents, teachers and the student themselves. It is important that the assessments are age appropriate and relevant to where the student is currently in his or her transition planning. Engaging parents and school members can also be accomplished in a variety of ways. Prior to the meeting an informal or formal survey or questionnaire can be sent home to assist in gathering information. Members can also hold an open conversation at the IEP team meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Alexandra Waite, Interboro School District - Prospect Park School
Body:
We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by utilizing both formal and informal assessments. Student interviews are a great informal assessment of student preferences, while interest inventories are a more formal assessment. 
We can support students by assessing and reassessing them to see how they have grown and how their preferences may have changed over time. We can include parents/families by gathering their input of hopes/concerns for the student and their observations from the home and community setting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lori Harmon-West Shore School District
Body: It is important to use both formal and informal assessments to collect meaningful information on students strengths, needs, and interests. It is important to have open communication with parents to see what their plans and their student's future plans look like. Parents and students need to know that it is ok if the plan changes from one year to the next.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tim Fanning - Interboro SD
Body: We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by focusing on the selection of instruments and methods that provide student-focused answers/data.  It is crucial to allow for student/parent input early on in the process and throughout the duration.  Allowing  their voice will lead to meaningful and purposeful results that will greatly benefit the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Justine Fernandes- City Charter High School
Body: In order to produce MPSG's that are in alignment we must use an informal transiiton assessment and a formal transition assessment. You can determine which type of assessment for informal and formal are appropriate depending on what the student wants to do after high school as well as what skills they might need to work on more. In order to get families involved I always ask for parental input and use that input to determine what type of assessment to give the student this way we can have an active conversation about their transition goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mikaela Quintois, West Shore School District
Body: To ensure that the students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are aligned with their preferences by collecting both formal and informal data. This data could include student and parent surveys, student interviews and teacher reports and observations. To include and support students and family members throughout the process, we should start discussing preferences early on. It is beneficial to hold meetings with all of the team members and provide useful resources to students and families.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nicole Taylor - West Shore School District
Body: To ensure students' transition assessment results are in alignment we can offer a series of formal and informal assessments to teams.  Teams select which assessments with individual students to ensure results producing MPSGs that are in alignment with students goals. Another important component is engaging the family and other stakeholders in the process.  It truly needs to be a collaborative team approach.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danielle Mowery- Line Mountain High School. Amy Dunn- LEA
Body:
Formal and informal assessments are both excellent ways to ensure that a students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with the students plans.  Student surveys (done more than once) are an excellent way to get firsthand information from the student.  These interviews will determine what type of formal assessment would be most appropriate.  Parent input throughout the year, including the IEP meeting is also beneficial.


By including school personnel and family members in all meetings is a great way to everyone in the loop and involved. Also, including both the parents and the appropriate school personnel to discuss course selection is another way to have all IEP team members actively involved and on the same page.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Rebecca Mausteller - Line Mountain School District
                                      Amy Dunn LEA

In order to have MPSG's in alignment with the student's postsecondary goal, input from both student and parent needs to be obtained.  Students will complete a transition survey each year along with informal conversations with their teacher to help determine their plan and activities to prepare for after high school.  It is important to get information from parents about their child's plans at the IEP meeting each year.  Having parents be involved with the transition planning is important.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Homoki, West Shore School District
Body:
We can ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by making sure we use a series of ongoing and differentiated informal and formal assessments (interest inventory, personality inventory, assessments of targeted skills, etc.)  
Including parents and multiple stakeholders can be done by gathering interest and buy in from members of the team, ensuring that they realize each team member is crucial to and responsible for the transition plan if it is to be successful. .
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Deurlein - Central Greene School District
Body: We can ensure students' transition assessemtn results are in alignment with preference and goals by collecting formal and informal data that include student and parent interviews, teacher reports, a career planning checklist, and career education.  We can ensure we are supporting those we serve by ensuring we are age/developmentally appropriate, and collected periodically as skills develop and interests change.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Barto-Quaker Valley High School- Mike Lewis
Body: The most essential participants of the IEP team that need to be included to ensure that MPSGs are aligned are the parents and the student, in addition to the teachers and outside service providers.  Inventories should be given in order to gauge the students' interests, strengths, and needs as well.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sherri Emrich, Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body:
Some ways we can ensure that students' transition assessments results produce measureable post-secondary goals that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams are to keep them age-appropriate, ongoing planning that involve the student, family, and IEP team.  It is important to include both informal and formal assessments and to keep information updated. Assessments should be relevant and student focused. 

Some ways to include and support students, parents/family, and school personnel engagement in the transition assessment is to introduce them early and as often as possible. Hold team meetings to discuss transition and obtain input from everyone involved. Provide the student and family resources in the community that can help support post-secondary goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Hoff - West Shore School District
Body: In order to ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams there need to be a series of informal and formal assessments given. These assessments should be on-going and age-appropriate. Another important aspect of transition assessments is that they are done throughout the year and not just annually in preparation of the IEP meeting. Assessments should change over the years and narrow in closer on specific transition related skills closer to exiting high school. Transition assessments should engage multiple stakeholders (student, teachers, parents, agency representatives, job coaches, etc.).  to gain multiple perspectives and ideas for planning purposes. Documenting assessments is also very helpful for agencies and determining eligibility and eliminate duplicating assessments.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Eric Healy - West Shore School District
Body: The IEP team must include parents and students in this process and gather their interests, strengths, needs, hopes, and dreams.  This can be done via formal and informal assessments.  Nothing is in stone but we must have quantifiable data points of input that anchor our plan.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: April Smith (West Shore School District)
Body: Choosing informal and formal transition assessments appropriately and knowing what each assessment assesses can assist in ensuring results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with the students preferences, future plans and dreams.  It is really important students complete transition assessments but it is also important to engage the family as well in transition planning for their child by also having them complete parent transition assessments about their child.  A full team approach to transition planning for student can ensure the student is engaging in potential post  secondary aspects to help the student meet their post secondary goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lauren DelBaugh- West Shore School District
Body: Assessments must be informal and formal. The IEP team, including parents and student, must meet regularly to find student interests, where they currently are and where they plan to go. They should be finding strengths and weaknesses in order to help the student meet their goals. The data and goals should align in order for a successful outcome. Students should also know that plans may change and that is ok.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Samantha Hagg-Northwest Tri County IU 5/NE School District
Body: We can ensure student's transition assessments produce MPSGs that are aligned to a child's hopes and dreams through thoughtful planning and appropriate dialogue between educators, parents/guardians/and the student. From the outset, it is important to look at transition planning as a coordinated effort that not only examines multiple formal and informal assessments but also uses that information to look at interests, perceptions, and skills. By delving into all of those areas, we can create individualized plans that support a student where they are to help them get where they dream to be.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Bill Barton-DuBois ASD
The student should be actively involved in the assessment process. Once assessments are completed it is important to talk with the students about their results and what it all means.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brian Keyser- Jamestown Area School District
Body: I have found that one of the best ways to ensure that MPSGs are in alignment with future plans is to have "real conversations" with the student and parents/guardians to look at their present level of functioning and achievement and work together to set goals that are attainable and, at the same time, realistic.  I read in Allison's case study that one of the fears her parents had was wasting money on postsecondary schooling for Allison, especially if it was not preparing her for career and life path.  It's a fine line to walk when having these conversations, as no professional educator ever wants to dampen the dreams of one of their students.  However, being creative in utilizing the interests and wants of the student is key.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: April Burchell - Montgomery Area School District
Body: Some ways we can ensure assessment results produce MPSGs in alignment with student preferences and goals are by evaluating assessments and what information they provide, using a variety of assessments including formal and informal, and working with others to have a wide variety of assessment knowledge and availability.   Ways to include and support student, parent and school personnel engagement in the assessment process is by using a variety of assessments that include students, parents and other school personnel.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Patti Micknis - DuBois Area School District
Body: We can ensure that student’s transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment by including the student in each step of the process.  They need to know that we are here to facilitate their future goals and make sure they have the correct courses, agency assistance, and supports to help them achieve their career goals.  By using appropriate, on-going assessments, we can monitor and adapt the student’s goals to move them closer to meeting their anticipated outcome.  Continued communication with the student's parent will ensure that all members of the team are helping the student move toward their career goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Morgan Levitz- West Shore School District
Body:
We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by using informal and formal assessments to obtain information in all of these areas from all stakeholders including the student, the parents/caregivers, special and general education teachers, etc. By evaluating these areas using on-going assessment we can make sure that any changes are updated within the IEP. 
We can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the on-going transition process by communicating clearly with all members of the IEP team. It is also important to focus on the “on-going” portion of this process. Changes occur and it is important that all team members are on the same page as the student grows, interests change, and strengths/needs continue to develop.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shari Brenizer- West Shore School District
Body:
The way that we can ensure that MPSGs are aligned with the students preferences, future plans, and dreams is by offering a variety of informal and formal assessments that will provide age appropriate and meaningful information.  The assessments also need to provide comprehensive information and instructional needs.  

We can support students and families in the transition assessment process by communicating with them on what assessments are being administered and what information we want to get from each assessment.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jackie Reed- Bradford Area School District
Body:
Typically we begin transition assessments at age 14 and the student not only has input, but is able identify areas of need in order for them to be successful; that could be academically in math or reading, working on social skills or possibly coping skills needed for the workplace.
Some of our students goals are tied into their transition plans. Such as increased reading comprehension or math computation skills.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Strait, McConnellsburg High School, LEA: Holly Varner
Body: We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by providing a variety of informal and formal assessments and speaking with student/parent and teachers. This process should be ongoing as interests can change as the student progresses through high school.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Kozich-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: Assessments must be both formal and informal; students should be provided a variety of assessments throughout. Monitoring of the results must be on-going and reviewed throughout the student's educational career.  Parents should also be involved in this process, as they can provide valuable information to the team, and offer supports as well. Students need to feel that they are seen, heard and valued throughout the transition process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jordan Cernaloger - Central Greene School District
Body: Formal and Informal assessments must be used during the transition planning process. Students interests can and will change from the time transition planning begins, so surveys and assessments must be done regularly. Results should be reviewed with the student to ensure that they are accurate. That data should be used to produce measurable goals for the student. Also parents/guardians, regular education teachers, any support staff and others should be involved in transition planning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Emma Klesen- Central Greene School District- Edith Woods
Body: To ensure that MPSGs are in alignment, we can use a variety of formal and informal assessments. Incorporating a variety of assessments allow for both feedback from in and out of school. This will help for the IEP team to create the best goals for the student. The IEP team can be in contact with and meet or speak with the student and their family's to ensure support in the transition.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rose Chiprich-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: By selecting appropriate transition services and activities, this will ensure that the student's goals are in alignment.  These assessments should be both formal and informal.  Parents and students should complete surveys each year to obtain more information and keep the information aligned to the student's IEP.  A student may attend votech one year and then the next year, decide that it's not the right career path for them.  The information gathered should then be used to write the IEP and goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sarah Wright - West Jefferson Hills School District
Body: Transition assessments should be completed both formally and informally. To ensure meaningful data is retrieved it is important to include the student as well as their family in the planning process continuously.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melanie Kijowski- Central Greene School District- Edith Woods
Body: Assessments should be both formal and informal. The IEP team should meet with the student and the parents to get info in order to know the student's interests.  This would allow the for meaningful data and information for the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Alissa Fox-Central Greene SD-Edith Woods
Body: Assessments for transition needs should be both formal and informal.  Students and parents should both be included to provide meaningful information to align data and goals for a successful outcome.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelsey Tate - Central Greene School District - Edith Woods
Body:
Informal and formal assessments should be given throughout the student's academic career, regularly, as their interests, abilities and skill set often change dramatically. If we, as a team, are meeting regularly to assess, discuss, and give opportunities to the student, we can then create measurable goals based off of what the student's interests are. 

As a school counselor, I know the importance of meeting with students one-on-one, as they often open up and speak about things they wouldn't in a group setting (like an IEP meeting). This goes for parents as well- keeping them in the loop and talking to them one-on-one throughout their child's transition planning stage is of the utmost importance so that they can foster and support their child's interests and goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jeff Coss-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: Transition assessments are very valuable, they can be used so much for planning purposes.  If a student is interested in college then the SAT's/ACT's must be scheduled.  If you know 8th grade they want to be a hair dress then you can schedule them to their local Technology Center to learn the appropriate skills.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rebecca Karluk-Central Greene-LEA Edith Woods
Body:
Assessment results must be both formal and informal.  These results must be continuously reviewed with the IEP team throughout the students high school career.  All involved must be aware of the students strengths and weakness in order to help the student either meet their career goals or to help the student explore other career options.  
In order to support and engage all parties, everyone must be included in the decision making process.  Parent and students must feel like their voice is heard and their input is a part of the transition process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Diane Supancik--Mountain View--LEA--Erica Loftus
Body:
Both informal and formal assessments are an important tool to help gather information about how a student/parents/teachers views student strengths, interests, and weaknesses.  It is important that the IEP team has conversations  to make sure that everyone is on the same page with transition planning.
   We give transition assessments yearly, as a student’s needs and interests change.  Working with 7th and 8th grade students, many times they have no idea what they want to do once they graduate. It is important for the students to know it is okay to change their mind, and their future is not set in stone.  We just want them to start thinking about what they may want to do after high school so that we may provide them the best education and skills possible.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tina Williams North East School District
Body:
LEA-Brianne Hodges

Selecting  transition assessments that are appropriate for the student is very important.  Each assessment no matter if formal or informal must help provide answers to one or more of the transition plan domains. Without proper data it is impossible to create MPSGs that are in alignment with the students preferences and future transition goals.  To help all members of the transition team to be engaged during this ongoing process, communication and data access is key.  The student with guidance from his/her transition team should be collecting and organizing his/her data in a way that leads to meaningful discussion about the student’s future goals and the needs that are required to be meant to achieve them.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melissa Franks, Susquehanna Community (Joni Deakin)
Body: Using both Formal and Informal transition assessments that are appropriate for the individual is extremely important.  Finding the right assessment for students can be a challenge at times.  Assessments need to be the right fit in order to be a meaningful part of the IEP for each individual student.  Parents don't always offer support that is needed so educators need to be diligent in this process.  Continued communication within the IEP team will assist in aligning the transition goals with the MAG's.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: VailIU1Itinerant-Carmichaels
Body:
Some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams are to complete all informal and formal assessments. We should always consider where the student is presently, where they are goin and how do we get them there. The assessments should focus on student focused answers. 
Some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process is to send home periodic goal checklists to members of the team so that as students/parents goals change they are kept up to date and aligned with the transition process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mary Harris - Northeast Bradford School District
Body:
Both informal and formal assessments are an important tool to help gather information about how a student a views their strengths, interests, and weaknesses. These assessments should also be given at least yearly, as a student’s needs and interests change.  Working with 7th and 8th grade students, many times they have no idea what they want to do once they graduate.  I make sure they know it is okay to change their mind, we just want to try to get them thinking about what it is they want to do once they graduate from high school so we can make sure they will be successful.  

It is important that the IEP team has conversations with the student's families/ parents to make sure that everyone is on the same page with transition planning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Terri Rader - Central Fulton
Body: I used different transition assessments each year with students so they aren’t becoming too familiar with the assessment questions. Also I gather data from sources other than the parents and students.  Our guidance counselors have started using Xello this year. Our County CareerLink Office teaches a Career Class twice a year in our high school and our guidance counselor works with me to recruit students on my caseload to take the course. The CareerLink representative also offers summer work programs for students and many of the students take advantage of these opportunities. By gathering information from different sources I am finding the student’s transition information to be more accurate and informative for planning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Chad Smith- South Allegheny
Body: An affective use of assessments and informal conversations with the students and families should remain fluid. They will change and so will the career pathways.  We use Xello, which many of our students believe is valuable and insightful.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Paige Bodenschatz-WSSD
Body:
Transition assessments used for students should be meaningful and meant to provide students with the opportunity to find things that interest them and what they might be good at.  Giving them multiple assessments help identify their wants, needs, and strengths.  
Including families into this process, allows them to understand their students needs and strengths as well as open the line of communication for their future post high school.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sheri Ransom - Mountain View School District
Body:
The student should complete a variety of formal and informal assessments which will assist in the conversation of setting goals and developing a vision with student and family.  Transition assessments will allow for discussion about career interest areas; work conditions preferred; independent living choices etc. This information can assist in developing MPSG that will align and support the student in building skills to be successful as they move forward.
    The assessments will be able to lead to connecting the students to the right transition activities, agency involvement and community resources available. 
    Our district has developed a Transition Assessment tracking sheet for 7th through 12th grade.  This ensures that our students are completing a variety of assessments in addition to the career readiness they receive through our school counselors and targeted classes they take throughout their jr/sr high school career.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nina Zimmerman, Berlin Brothersvalley School District
Body: We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSG’s that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by completing student interviews and career interest inventories each year. A student interview would allow the student to state what they are interested in and may help drive transition goals. Career interest inventories can also shed light on transition goals, because it will help the student explore the skills necessary for each particular career cluster. Transition goals must be realistic and attainable. Educators can and should include a variety of individuals when gathering input for IEPs and holding IEP meetings such as parents/family members, other school stakeholders (related services), outside agencies for job training, post-secondary education, and adult day care settings. Yearly parent interviews and observations from various stakeholders are also provide insight into the transition process. These measures should be ongoing throughout the educational process so that adjustments can be made at any time.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Maureen Donlevy Smith-West Shore School District
Body: Assessments need to be appropriate for the student.  I think our transition coordinator has done a great job of curating a list we can use. Also, our district has dedicated one class period per month to transition for the entire school so we are getting varied assessments for data on our students.   I find it is as helpful to rule out things for students as it is to zero in on exactly what they want. Body:
To create MPSGs that align with a students preferences, future plans, and goals, both informal and formal assessments may be used.  Informal assessments may include: observations, interviews, field experiences, and teacher reporting.  Formal assessments may include: interest inventories, self assessments, skill and employability assessments, adaptive behavior assessments, or use of a task analysis checklist.  It is important to note that there is no single assessment protocol but the protocol used must be appropriate for that student and their age.

There are various ways to support students, parents/family members, and school personnel in the transition assessment process.  Students, staff, and family members may be interviewed. Body: To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams, we need to be sure that we are utilizing both formal and informal assessments as often as possible so we have plenty of information to review and discuss.  All members of the IEP team (student, families, teachers, related service providers, etc.) should be included in the ongoing transition process.  The input from all members of the IEP team is valuable in assisting with the transition process.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Preslee Riccio- ECASD

It is critical to maintain yearly assessments (formal & informal) to keep MPSGs aligned.  Student interests and capabilities are constantly changing, if we don't adjust the MPSGs to those student changes we will fail to keep them aligned.

LEA- Leslie Gleghorn
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Katie Gerakaris- Interboro SD
Body:
Rachel Lambert/Ryan Synder

Some of the ways to align transitions results is to use informal and formal assessments to gather the information. Making sure to review the students goals after high school is important to do every year. Making a plan with the student on how/when things need to be accomplished in order to reach their goals before graduation will keep family, student, and guidance counselor's on the same page- therefore can keeping everyone engaged. Reviewing this information yearly will keep everyone in the loop of the student's ultimate goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy Rohrbach- Brandywine Heights SD
Body: In order to produce MPSGs, transition assessments must be appropriate for the age of the student and the type of information you are looking to gather from it. It is important to use a variety of assessments, both formal and informal, throughout the year. It is also important to be sure you gather data from all team members- student, parent, teachers, etc. By incorporating data from all people invested and from all types of tools, you can be sure to produce MPSGs for the student's transition plan.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Larissa Leuenberger-EFSD-Gephart
Body: Students' transition assessment results produce aligned MPSGs by using a variety of assessments such as Formal and Informal, surveys, talking to and including the parents and all IEP team members.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy Repko/Kayla Pollacci - Duquesne City School
Body:
In order to ensure that transition assessments produce MPSGs it is important to chooses the right assessment for each student. Assessments included should be both informal and formal, should include both student and parent information and address each area of post-secondary life. 

In order to include and support students, parents/family members, and school
personnel in the on-going transition process it is important to work as a team. Students and parents must feel a part of the planning and the planning must work for students, families, and the school. For example if a student has expressed going to vo-tech it will be important to hear what that child is saying and provide them the information and opportunity to meet their goals and discusses the appropriates with the family and school team.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Cathy Grieb - JVSD - LEA Lisa Coble
Body: Using a variety of assessments and assessing at least once per year can ensure MPSGs that are aligned.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Elisa Yanovich - Brandywine Heights Area School District
Body: To ensure that transition assessment results are valid and appropriate, the IEP team should look at a comprehensive picture of the student. To do that, various forms of data should be collected and used. Formal and informal assessments used together will help the team gain well-rounded insight on the student. The student should also play a large role as they are the primary source of information. These goals are based on their interests, wants, needs, etc. Assessments used should vary and should also be age-appropriate. Family input is also vital and necessary to writing meaningful goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Deborah Riccobelli - Quaker Valley
Body:
To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that align with their preferences, plans, and dreams, schools must adopt a comprehensive approach to using varied transition assessments, both formal and informal.  The assessments should provide enough essential information to help create the roadmap of identifying where students are, where they want to go, and how to get there.  If questions remain, additional assessments may be necessary.

To include and support students and their parents/family school should involve them in all aspects of the IEP process and ensure student and parent/family interviews are part of the informal assessment process.  Also, students can help with the creation and maintenance of documentation portfolios.  This approach provides increased ownership and the likelihood that the MPSGs will align with the student's preferences and plans.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mandie Szakelyhidi- ECASD
Body: The IEP team needs to appropriately assess each student appropriately and identify his or her needs and goals and make a plan to meet those needs based on the data from the assessments.  Informal assessments such as teacher observations and informal interviews should not be discounted.  The student should be involved in goal setting from the beginning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Deibler, Brandywine Heights Area School District
Body: The IEP team needs to look at where the student is now, where they are going, and how they will get there. They then need to pick appropriate assessments that align with the student's needs and goals. These assessments should be age appropriate and vary from year to year. It is also important to make sure that the student's family is involved early and as often as possible.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carmen Megivern, Susquehanna Community SD, LEA- Joni Deakin
Body: Measurable Postsecondary Goals that align with student performances, interests and needs can be achieved by involving the student and parent as an ongoing process throughout the school year.  Students change their ideas and become more realistic as their awareness and exposures are increased, so regular conversations, activities and formal assessment will help gear individuals in their future outcomes.  Creating and or choosing assessments/inventories that show the "whole" student can also ensure that the team is aware of every change that occurs to realign and keep the student on track towards their goal/outcome.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Catherine Grieb- JVSD-LEA Lisa Coble
Body: Use a variety of formal and informal assessments.  Communicate with the student an parents
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carol E. Kuper-Pyle - ECASD
Body: Measurable Postsecondary Goals (MPSGs) that align with student's preferences, interests and needs can be achieved by actively involving both the student and the parents yearly. Using various assessments each year and building upon or changing outcomes based upon the information gathered.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Bill Guess - Connellsville Area School District
Body: Ensuring student transition assessment results produce MPSG's that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams begins with informal and formal transition collection data.  Ongoing communication with the student, supporting family, and IEP team until the student graduates or ages out will help in student success.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Leslie Gleghorn - Ellwood City Area SD
Body: Transition planning is a dynamic process that is the result of communication with the IEP team members, formal and informal assessments and overall academic strengths and weaknesses.   It would be unlikely if the IEP team and a student had the same goals and plans at age 13 as they do at age 17 or 18. As students develop socially, emotionally, academically, we also see a development in their goals for their future.  Not only do we require annual input from students and parents via interest inventories, general conversation, but also check ins with students as they find certain classes interesting and continue to develop future interests.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mark Strosnider- Intermediate Unit #1
Body: The way that we can ensure that student's transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams is by using good communication. Transition planning is an on-going process that requires a variety of informal and formal assessments. Communicating with the student and their family allows you to keep up to date with the students interests and helps develop the most effective transition plan for that school year. It is important to check in regularly with younger students because the goals for their futures often changes from year to year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Susan Kramer, Interboro SD, Lisa Ford
Body: Transition Interest Inventories are helpful in identifying student interest or if a student already knows what they want to do, the team should discuss the steps the student needs to take to achieve their goals. The MSPGs should include their growth towards those steps or post secondary outcome.  The results to any transition assessment should be shared with the family and school personnel and added to the IEP. The family should also be given a transition assessment to gain an idea of what a student needs to learn to be as independent as possible.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dana Stelitano-ECASD/Leslie Gleghorn
Body: Formal and informal assessments are necessary to monitor alignment with goals and communication skills. It's essential that all team members of an IEP have an opportunity to add input for the student's success.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: DeAnna McMillen-ECASD
Body:
To insure the goals are measurable, both informal and formal assessments would both be valuable.  Formal interest inventories as well as input from the student and family would both help insure the student in on a proper path.  In addition, this process should be ongoing and change as the student's interests change.
Allowing the family and student to all have a voice will help insure a positive experience and provide the correct path for the student.  Also, having a variety of teachers' input would insure the student is focusing on their particular strengths.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Karen McGann-Belmont Charter Network
In order to reflect the needs, interests and desires of a student the Transition Assessment must be designed to solicit from the student their individual desires, interests and future goals. This information can then support the creation of MPSG's that align with the individual and assist in the alignment of the development of the IEP.
 Communication from the school informing familes of upcoming career/tranition activities, opportunities and guidance that the school provides on a daily basis. Opportunities for family involvement in some of those activities. Critical is the active involvement of the familes/parents in the development of the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lacretia Lachnicht-IU6 Redbank Valley
Body: Ensure assessments present a picture of the whole student. Review of transition goal progress annually at IEP's would be helpful for all especially families as they prepare for transition.  This opportunity would allow the team to be informed of any changes that need to be made.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lacretia Lachnicht, OTR/L
Body: It is important to make sure the specific targeted skills for the career choice are assessed. If the student has a bilateral coordination deficit or fine motor dexterity delay then a career that requires those skills may not be in alignment.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Samantha Wheeler, Kristina Bokulich (LEA)
Body:
To produce aligned MPSGs, a variety of formal and informal assessments need to be used in order to assist students in identifying their preferences after graduation.  Assessments need to be ongoing as plans and dreams are likely to change from year to year.  
Student and family involvement is key when discussing plans for the future.  Hopefully an entire team meeting can be set up in order to show support to the student and family and brainstorm different ways that student will be able to achieve their goals for the future.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amelia Loughlin - School Dist of Phila - AMY NW
Body: In order to produce MPSGs that are in alignment with students' future plans, we must include a variety of formal and informal assessments.  Transition assessments must be ongoing so that they remain age appropriate as a student gets older and closer to transition.  All stakeholders must be involved in the process, especially the student themselves.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Andrew Lugg- RIU/Redbank Valley
Body: Always good to keep in mind a student's experiences and family input when selecting an assessment for a visually impaired student. If the student's experiences have been limited their understanding of the skills they will need to train for a future job. An assessment for a visually impaired student should be detailed enough to discover if the student has an unrealistic understanding of possible career paths.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Adamson - IU6/DuBois Area
Body:
To ensure students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences and plans, we should make sure to use a variety of assessments, and that assessments are appropriate to the student, grade level, etc, and are updated. 

Maintaining communication between all team members is essential in supporting and including students and the entire team in this process. Group emails, meetings, etc, plus asking for input from all team members about the process can help with communication.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Mariam Bankovich - IU 6/Redbank Valley
As a school physical therapist, it is important to observe the student's movement and function and use assessments to identify mobility needs. Then based on these needs, working with the student and educational team to develop a program/goals that addresses the needs identified and support the student's MPSGs to align with their preferences and future plans.   As the student achieves goals, assessment needs to be ongoing and new goals continuously developed to promote progression of skills and alignment with future plans.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Andrew Lugg- IU 6/Redbank Valley
Body: It is good to always remember that there are no (none) normed assessments for visually impaired students on ANYTHING. Thus, assessment result for Vision Support students need to be viewed critically. Their needs and interests can be very different from their similarly situated peers.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dina Bickel-RIU6/Redbank Valley
Body: A variety of assessments is important as it will show a consistent preference across the board and help to create appropriate goals.  It is also important for the teacher to understand the students skills and/or interests, but it is equally important for the teacher to direct the student according to his/her capabilities.  For example the student wants to be a veterinarian but the teacher knows the students disability will inhibit that choice.  The teacher will need to find alternative career choice in that realm that will satisfy the student
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jocelyn Bryson - Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: There are many ways that the student’s transition assessment results produce MPSG’s that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans and dreams in a variety of ways.  Choosing the appropriate assessments is one way to ensure the results align with their specific case.   Some ways to include everyone in the assessment process, could include: a variety of assessments chosen for each student, include surveys or interviews  to ensure all school personnel and parent/family input is being shared, and student input and preferences could be discussed with student directly before the meeting or during the meeting to ensure their preferences are included.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Selena Magagnotti-IU6
Body: To produce MPSGs, it is important to maintain ongoing assessments and revise the IEP as needed to keep the information relevant.  By providing interviews to the student and families that determine interests, future plans, and other relevant information, we can learn what the students' goals may be.  Data collection (formal and informal assessments) and parent interviews, we are including others in the transition assessment process.  We also need to ensure that the goals are measureable and well written to reflect that.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Edith Woods- Central Greene SD
Body:
Having available a variety of formal and informal transition assessments is important.  Student, parent and teacher interviews are extremely important to help determine what transition assessments might be a good fit for the student and parent to utilize.  
Reaching out to students, parents/family members, and school personnel in a variety of formats.  Some may prefer a phone call.  Others may prefer a face-to-face conversation.  Others may prefer written forms or online forms.  Email is another communication option.  As with determining the appropriate transition assessments, it is also important to find agreed upon communication methods.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jessica Kalmar - Redbank Valley
Body:
Team members can ensure that students’ transition assessments produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by collecting data through use of formal and informal assessments. This data can help highlight important aspects of the transition that need included in the MPSGs. 

Students, family members, and school personnel can be included in the transition assessment on-going process by using long-term surveys and questionnaires. These surveys can be administered twice yearly to ensure team members have a chance to express concerns over time as new developments may arise.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Madison Johnson- Redbank Valley
Body:
To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs are aligned with their preferences, future plans, and dreams, it is critical to keep updated data over time on the student. By keeping updated data by using appropriate assessments will keep plans and dreams appropriate and achievable.

Communication between all professionals and family is key. To keep communication open and continuous, I have been apart of group emails with other professionals and families. I have also used methods such as phone calls, emails and paper notes with parents. When the parents are involved in the communication process it allows for a good carryover of skills and strategies over. It is also important to include all support personnel as well, this way all individuals involved can provide the student with support he or she may need.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Craig Allegretto-ErieSD-ELBS
I feel the best way to have quality MPSGs is to have different assessments from the time the student is of transition age to their final years leading up to graduation.  We all go through different likes and dislikes as we grow.  The idea is to make sure we are keeping up with the students interests.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Joshua Hindman - Redbank Valley
Body:
To produce MPSGs in alignment with the student's goals we need to use appropriate assessments that take into account student preferences, plans, and dreams. We also need to make sure we're using a variety of assessments to get a complete picture of the student, their goals, their interests, what support they have in place, etc. 

To ensure everyone is included in the transition process I think ongoing communication is vital. Allowing multiple team members to complete assessments is one way to do this. I've also been involved in cases where there is a group email for the student that includes teachers, support personnel and parents which makes communication easy.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michael Boston - Redbank Valley School District - LEA Mr. Josh Temchulla
Body:
Some ways to ensure assessment results produce proper measurable post-secondary education goals include identifying informal and formal assessments that require the students to provide detailed information on their career choices.  Incorporating a variety of assessments (such as interest surveys, skills surveys, personality assessments, etc.) can provide a well-rounded view of the student and help to point the information in the direction of an MPSG.  

To engage IEP team members in the process, it requires ongoing communication.  This means sending out check-in e-mails regularly (such as once per month or quarter) with updates on IEP transition goals, whether or not service activities were completed (and how they went), what next steps are, and probing questions that would engage parents, students, teachers, and other school personnel in the process.  A checklist can also provide a tangible way to identify what tasks have been completed and what ones need to be targeted in the next quarter to stay on track.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Delaney Wolfe- Redbank Valley
Body:
To ensure we are providing quality MPSGs, we should be administering a variety of assessments. We should also be collaborating with other educators involved in transition for assistance or guidance.

To include others in the transition assessment, we must truly work as an an IEP *team*. We can ask for input or have team members complete appropriate assessments. I also think that we should be more effectively communicating the reasoning behind transition plans to students and their families. I find that transition is often breezed over during the IEP meeting and students/families are often left confused.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Alexandria Vallimont-North East School District (ELBS)
Body: The best way to ensure that the students transition assessments produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future dreams and plans is to administer multiple age appropriate assessments that are both formal and informal assessments. This is the same way to include support systems such as parents, school personnel, etc. By using multiple forms of assessment throughout the entire transition process we can include parent interviews or informal questions.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carrie Witherite- DuBois Area School District
Body: To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams, we need to collect a variety of age appropriate and ongoing data. We need to make sure that the whole team is involved. It is important for everyone involved to be aware of the goals the student is working toward for their future plans. We need to talk with parents and give them information for any available resources.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dianne Keller- (Elizabeth Forward School District) Keith Gephart
Body:
How can an educator make certain that the student's transition assessment can be useful in developing future plans for the IEP? The assessment must be age and ability appropriate.  It will need to give an idea of what the student can do in order to show what skills the student may need to master in order to meet their career goal.  This is where the MPSG lays. 

What are some ways to include the student, family, and teachers in this on-going process of assessment? The family needs to listen the student's career desire and provide opportunities for the student to attempt to reach the goal at home as well as at school. A unified, organized support system that sees what the student can do, listens to what the student wants to do, and provides the opportunities to attempt the needed skills will help get the  transition goal attaining job done.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Rees, DuBois Area High School, LEA - Torie Sedor
Body:
In order to ensure that transition assessment results of students produce MPSGs in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams;  it is important to complete formal and informal assessments at least yearly along with more frequent assessment for progress monitoring purposes.  As we scaffold and teach skills such as independence, organization, and planning; we need to be cognizant of the fact that they need assistance in monitoring and meeting goals and that their goals and plans may change.  We need to keep all team members involved and fluid throughout the process in order for help our students achieve their best and to continually monitor progress and make any revisions necessary along the way if the student should choose a different directional path throughout the course of the IEP.  

We can and should include and support students, family members, and school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process through the assessments themselves.  There are multiple types of forms to be completed, student centered, parent centered, and teacher centered; all which are important and all which bring a different perspective to the transition plan.  It is also important to have frequent contact with each team member for progress monitoring purposes.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Janey London, DASD, LEA: Robert Kriner
Body:
The ways that we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams is simply by including them in the process.  Have students talk about what their goals/dreams are, complete asssessments geared to their interests and create post secondary goals with their intrests and needs in mind.

Some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process is by commucating where the student is in the process and if their are changes to their path.  Meetings are a great way to ensure commucation.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Cassie Hulick ECASD (Leslie Gleghorn)
Body: Producing successful MPSG's that are in alignment with a student's goals and future plans starts with planning. Assessments on their wants and needs should happen continually, not just once per year. Also, providing several types of assessments, interest inventories, etc to collect as much information as possible. Including families in the planning process is also crucial. Setting aside time during the school year to collect this information will allow for appropriate MPSGs. Education staff on available resources is also something that should be highly considered!
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lacey Lydick - DuBois School District
Body: To ensure MPSG's are aligned with students preferences, future plans, and dreams, it's important to use a variety of formal and informal assessments. The assessments need to be of good value and provide additional information to help with the students transition. Assessments should be related to the students future career path. The assessments should be given annually and should assess where the student is presently, what their future plan is, and steps needed to get there. It's important for the student, parents, special education teacher, transition coordinator, outside agencies, etc. to work collaboratively during the students high school career to achieve the students transitional goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Cristin Hickman, Dubois Area; (Supervisor Torie Sedor)     Informal and formal assessments are  important tools to help gather student interests. Assessments should also be given annually to allow for interests change. It is important that the IEP team has conversations with the student's families/ parents to ensure unity with transition planning. I feel that there is room for improvement with transition planning for students that have unrealistic goals.  Career research does assist with this however, it is still a concern
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heidi Woods - DuBois Area School District
Body: To ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that align with their preference, future plans and dreams teachers need to have the students complete a variety of informal and formal assessments.  The assessments need to be provided once a year or as often as a students needs, strengths or interests change.  Collaboration with the IEP team and outside agencies is very important during this process.   MPSG's are important so the team knows if the student is working toward goals that will benefit them throughout their lives.  The transition process should be ongoing throughout their high school years.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Stephanie Novak-DuBois Area School District
Body:
-We can ensure a student’s transition assessment results produce MPSGs in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by conducting frequent interest inventories, career readiness assessments, and independent living skills assessments. IEP team members want to ensure this is done frequently to provide the most accurate information for post-secondary goals. 
-Ensuring constant and consistent communication between home and school will keep all stake holders in the transition assessment process. Including information about the student’s goals and achievements, as well as including their current present levels by surveys about the students given to parents/family members and other school personnel.
