Subject: Raena Como-EFSD; LEA-Keith Gephart
Body:
1. Some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams are a variety of both informal and formal assessments. The assessments need to be aligned with the student's interests and age appropriate. 

2. Some ways that you can include parents and students in the transition assessment ongoing process are informal assessments, communication about transition, interviews, and parent input forms. Parent input forms needs to be relative to student demographics, age, and grade level.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Denise Hasis - EFSD; LEA - Keith Gephart
Body:
1.  What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams some ways are a variety of both informal and formal assessments.  The assessments need to be aligned with student's interests and age appropriate.  
2.Some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams is to provide them with both formal and informal age appropriate assessments. The assessment need to be aligned with the student's interest as well.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carrie Reynolds-DuBois Area School District/Middle School
Body: Giving a variety of assessments to students that are student-oriented, will give the IEP team a more collected data to use when making future decisions for each student. Including parent/family members through interviews and other forms of assessments/checklists in an ongoing manner, keeps the information current for the students MPSGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Annette Davis- DuBois Area School District
Body:
It is important to use a variety of assessment tools, formal/informal as well as involving all members of the IEP team and outside agencies to get different perspectives/input about results of assessments.  Interviews should occur yearly and when/if possible by different interviewers.  


Students and parents should be actively involved in/with assessments and results.  If an assessment produces results that provide some “surprising” data rather than disregard the assessment have team members provide input as maybe a new path has been discovered.  Also never use the same assessment tools over and over.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Henry Truman: DuBois Area School District
Body:
1. It’s important to use both formal and informal assessments that are relevant/current to ensure the MPSGs are in alignment. 
2. I feel that the best way to involve/support all parties (a student, their family, school personnel) is to give/receive regular updates, to keep an open line of communication and to make sure all are invited to meetings/trainings pertaining to the benefit of the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nicole Gralla, DuBois Area School District
Body:
Assessments are a very important tool to help gather information on how a student a views their strengths, interests, and weaknesses. Assessments should also be given yearly or multiple times a year as a student’s needs and interests change. 

It is important that the IEP team has conversations with the student's families/ parents to ensure everyone is on the same page with transition planning. This should be an on-going process. It is not something that only gets talked about once a year at the IEP meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dan Minns, DuBois Area High School
Body:
In order to ensure that student transition assessments results produce MPSGs, it is important to use both formal and informal types of assessment.  It is important to use a variety of assessments that will yield different information.  Most importantly, transitions is not just a once a year visit.  It is something that teachers, parents, students, agencies, potential employers, and so on  keep at the forefront of instructional lessons and activities.  It it also important that students move through the phases of transitions.  A student at the end of his/her senior year, should not be in the self awareness stage unless the student is changing career paths after multiple job shadow/work experiences at various sites. 

The best way to include and support students, families, and school personnel in the on-going transition assessment process is through open communication and sharing of information.  This may occur through e-portfolios where all relevant people have access.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lori Ardeno     Jefferson-Morgan School District
Body:
When transition planning, I believe it is important to use a variety of transition assessments. As a department, we have gathered a variety of assessments to use starting in 7th grade (providing they will be of transition age) and changing the assessments each year through the 12th grade as interests will change over the years. As students age, it is important that the assessments help narrow their field of interest and guide them on their career path. This information will help the team plan transition services from activities to courses and services the student will need while attending school and after graduation.


Parental involvement as well as student involvement is the key in planning transition services. Information garnered during informal assessments are as valuable as formal assessments. This is where you get to know your student as an individual. What your student likes and does not like; what their strengths and weaknesses are and they things that they have accomplished and plan on doing.
Author: Anonymous

Body: In order to ensure that the students transition assessment results create aligned MPSG's, is to make sure they answer their strengths, interests, preferences and future plans on a yearly basis following the Who am I? /Where am I going? /How do I get there? surveys, questionnaires and inventories as well as provide job shadowing and work based working experience opportunities with local businesses in the career interest areas to help build that bridge between the community and school district.  We can also support and inform the parent/family members by hosting monthly Transition Night meetings with guest speakers and send Parent Transition Surveys home to include them in the annual transition process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tammy Miller, BentonSD
Body: Assessments help collect written data on students thoughts and feelings on transition planning. Having conversations with them is also important to expand on the information given.  An assessment can be a great tool to start conversations with students and their families about their strengths and interests providing direction to future plans.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carin Manuud- PE&T Charter HS
Body:
It is important that the IEP team use assessments that are ongoing, frequent and varied, when determining a student's transition planning/programming. Using both formal and informal assessments (i.e. interest inventories, observations, student interviews, adaptive behavior assessments etc.) will provide a more comprehensive picture of the student's strengths, interests and goals. These assessments must be done regularly, as student interests constantly shift and change.

In order to include all parties in the transition planning process, ongoing communication and regular participation in IEP meetings is vital. Input should constantly be gathered from the student, parents and school personnel
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Marsha Stellfox, EPASD - LEA, Colleen Livingston

There are many ways that we can ensure that the transition plans aligns with the students future plan. When you know your student well, you are better able to focus on their needs. This can come from informal observations, data collection, conversations with the student, parent and other teachers.  Transition assessments should also be used to help with this.  We need to remember that teenagers do change their minds and we need to keep up with them so that their goals are appropriate for them. 

We can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment in several different ways. Students are included in the ongoing conversations throughout the year concerning transition. They also complete different transition activities throughout the school year, which include formal and informal inventories.   Parents are also  involved in the ongoing conversations concerning their student. Their information is included in the parent input section of the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Paul John Holberg - BASD
Body:
Having up to date information about the student’s future plans, interests and dreams will produce MPSGs that are in alignment.  Assessments that can be used are transition questionnaires, interest inventories and surveys. Using this information you have an updated IEP that will include the most up to information about the students wants and needs.  Knowing this information will allow all team members to be on the same page.        


The biggest stakeholders other than the students themselves are their parents. It is a necessity to include them in this process.  Communication is key to this process.  Teachers can send home questionnaires, emails or calls to the parents about updating the information on the IEP.  Having the most current information will allow everybody to work together, and have a better support system for the students.

The student survey can be done ahead of time in a 1:1 setting without the pressure of attending a larger meeting and speaking in front of a group if that would increase the comfort level for the student. School personnel need to be involved as well, by having all stakeholders on the same page the student has the opportunity to be exposed and experience activities that can confirm or question potential transition outcomes.

The best way to support the on-going engagement in transition assessment is to collaborate with related service providers, school staff, and outside agency staff by educating students and parents about the transition process at the building level and specifically discuss what type of supportive programs and transition resources are available to students.  For example, I always invite the special education transition coordinator to students' 9th grade IEP meetings. It is always helpful and comforting to put a name with a face and helps the TC to establish a rapport with students and parents. The TC and I discuss various work-based learning opportunities that are available to students.  Often times this discussion leads to students and parents opening up as to what they want their child to "try."  

For example, if a student knows they want to enter the workforce directly after graduating from high school to work either in retail or the food service industry, we can discuss and provide job shadowing or work-based learning experiences in each of these career-interest areas in order for the student to get a better "feel" as to what each industry is like and make a better, more-informed decisions as to where they want to obtain employment after graduating from high school.

It is important to get the student involved and active in their transition process as early as possible.  When the student is involved, open dialog can begin to have them explore possible pathways they would like to take in the future.  Parents and staff members should also take active roles in the process.  Staff members working with the student can provide detailed information about strengths and needs in each class the student attends.  They have been through the process many times before and can point out areas that may be overlooked.  Parents can provide insight to their goals for the child.  Parents are the support that has started the process and been involved each year.  They can provide more detailed information about what has changed in the past and what growth the student has made.
 
At the beginning of the process very simple surveys should be given to allow the student to explore and discover what may best fit them in the future.  Each year the assessments and surveys should become more focused on the skills that the individual student needs to be successful in their post secondary goals and independent living skills.

Subject: Sarah Eddy -  Central Greene School District

Some ways that we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams are to provide meaningful, ongoing assessments that can be used throughout the transition planning years. 

Parents should be involved in this process as well through open lines of communication, discussions with the IEP team and through realistic expectations for their child.

Subject: Laura Franks - Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: There are several ways to ensure students’ assessment results produce appropriate MPSGs that align to their future plans. One way is to have open communication with the student about their plans. It is important to create meaningful dialogue so that the student can share what their likes/dislikes, interests, and plans are. This communication should be ongoing and not just held during annual IEP Meetings. Another way is to provide age-appropriate transition assessments. It is important that these align with the student’s age, ability, and reading level so that accurate data can be collected. These assessments allow the IEP Team and Transition Coordinator to create a specific Transition Plan for the student.

Subject: Kelly Kocher- Benton Area SD
Body:
Some ways to ensure students assessment results produce appropriate goals for their future plans, is to converse with the student to determine what their plans actually entail so you can provide the best suited assessment. Not all student plans are cookie cutter, and neither are the multiple assessment options. 

Some ways to support students in the on-going transition process would be to fully explain to them each step as it comes up so they are fully included and understanding of the process.

Finally, provide families with resources of interests to help make them a part of the transition planning.

Body: Assessments should be directly aligned with the skills within the goals that have been developed in the IEP while also complying with any modifications that the student requires. The goals should be aligned based on the students' academic input of their strengths and needs. Assessments should be provided in both a formal and informal manner to monitor the students' ability to show growth and understanding of the skill being assessed. If a student is not displaying growth or understanding in the skill, the goal and/or assessment may need to be revisited and revised. ~ Corey Harrington

Parents and guardians need to be involved in the transition assessment process as well so that the goals we are creating are attainable and relative. Subject: Michelle Klinger - Elizabeth Forward School District
Body:
To ensure that a student’s assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams, the assessments have to completed frequently.  The assessments are not something that should just be done annually, when the student’s IEP is due.  This should be an ongoing process that is based on the individual student.  The assessments given must be appropriate and must add additional information that will provide a better understanding of the student’s interests and future goals. 

The formal assessments include interest inventories, self-determination assessments, skills and employability assessments, adaptive behavior scales, and task-analysis checklists.  The assessments chosen must be appropriate for the individual student.   The parent(s)/family members can be involved through parent interviews, frequent communication, IEP meetings, and formal assessments as well. The school staff members and IEP team must be in frequent communication to keep everyone knowledgeable of the student.  When it comes down to it, the entire team has to contribute in order for the transition process to go smoothly and be more effective for the student.

Subject: Taren Heinrich - West Shore School District
Body:
Assessments should be consistent and be focusing on what you want to see the student succeed in. They should be age appropriate and focus on their personal present levels. These MPSGs should focus on the students interests and personal plans and dreams, while being appropriate with their present levels. We need to look at where the student is presently, where they want to go and how we are going to get to that point. 

All members of the IEP team should be included in the development of each part of the MPSGs. They should be kept in the loop as changes are made and new pieces are added throughout the process. Involving the student is very important because the decisions made are going to affect their life after school.

Subject: Tara McCombie-Jefferson-Morgan School District
Body:
When deciding on Transition assessments, it’s important to gather different types of information from each student each school year; however, I believe that there should also be an assessment that is used consistently throughout the transition process to determine if the transition plan needs to be updated. At a very young age a student may decide they want to follow one career path and by the time they are in high school and has been exposed to additional transition assessments, students may have a more focused view on their strengths to guide them on their transition journey. Their journey becomes career specific.  This is valuable information to collect so transition goals can be adjusted throughout the student’s high school career. 


Getting Parents and students involved in this process is very important. I believe our parents are involved with this process through the completion of informal surveys regarding their child’s interests and needs. We have also helped both parents and students complete these forms through an interview process. 


With transition age students, I find students enjoy completing these surveys because this gives them the opportunity to showcase what they like, what they don’t like, what their strengths and what their weaknesses are. Student’s love to share with adults things that they have accomplished or things they are working towards accomplishing.

Holly Varner, Central Fulton School District

We need to utilize a students transition assessment to support their desired future outcomes.  The information provided by the student may not be what we would expect the student to do in the future.  We, as educators, need to take the student's information and assist them in looking at the future with realistic expectations and goals developed.  We need to work with the student's planning and review what is needed to reach their goals.  With this information from the student and with teaching and guidance involved, realistic goals can be written.

There are many ways in which we can support others during the transition process.   To me, it is very important to be open and honest about a student's skills and abilities.  Transparent communication with all involved will allow for the team to work together and do what is best for the student.  This will allow the student to see what they need to do and what they may need assistance in .  The plan needs to be reviewed and discuss with all involved to let all potential resources become active.

Subject: Brianne Hodges - North East School District
Body:
In order to assure that assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with student preferences, future plans, and dreams, planning and assessment must be ongoing.  It cannot be something that is done right before the IEP to complete a requirement.  Instead, the assessment and planning should be throughout the year, with both formal and informal assessments that are aimed at the individual student (not just a pre-determined set of assessments).
One way to support students and families in the ongoing transition assessment process is to be open and honest.  It is important that a positive relationship is established and ongoing, and communication of plans and results should also be ongoing.  It is important that everyone has an opportunity to provide input, but ultimately the focus should remain on the individual student.

Including members of the IEP team and families to complete transition surveys for the student is also helpful.

Properly aligned MPSGs are produced when secondary transition planning is ongoing through any given year with age appropriate assessments and a focus on career and adult living goals. It should include multiple stakeholders.  Post-secondary services should be developed and  ID'ed that will enable a student to make progress in their skill development and increase the likelihood in achieving their post-secondary goals. Outside agencies should involved those who offer job training/coaching and placement.  The job coach/agency should maintain contact with the new employer as well as the student, parents/guardians and teacher even after graduation.  Then they can make adjustments as needed.

Subject: Melinda Krebs, Northeastern/IU 12
Body:
When considering what the student and/or parent indicates through an informal survey, the formal assessment can provide data that should support the student's desires or support ways in which instruction can be supported to help the student achieve a desire in their MPSG. 
Future plans should always be fluid. I do not know how many of us are doing what we thought we would be doing at age 14, or even 18 but I certainly am not a lawyer or a music teacher! Our support as Educators should guide the student into providing them with as much information as possible to help them with their wishes.And that, can take time in the course of a school schedule. 
I don't know if there is one standard way to ensure that this can happen, but if a school district had a practice of looking over that Transition Assessment data at regular intervals during the year, perhaps that practice would help to inform instruction more "deeply"? Even just a verbal check-in related to Assessment data would let the student and parent know that the school district is "thinking about them" and I definitely feel that the Family Engagement piece is a natural extension of Secondary Transition, and just goes with the job.

Subject: Katie Geis- Elizabeth Forward School District
Body: We can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSG’s that are in alignment with their preferences by selecting the appropriate transition assessment that best fits the needs and goals of the student. Multiple assessments should be considered and utilized. We should be considering the expansion of our current data and the skills and experiences the student’s needs to successfully obtain their future goals. Transition planning is a fluid process, and the team should be investing time in collecting the most accurate data from the student and family. Transition assessment outcomes should leave the team with a clear plan for helping the students obtain their goals. Family members and students should understand the process and how valuable their input is throughout each step. Frequent feedback helps drive the next course of action and can steer the team in the best direction. Students should provide feedback from follow up activities that occur because of the outcomes of the assessments.

Subject: Shayne Smith - Elizabeth Forward School District
Body: We can ensure that transition assessment results produce MPSG's that are in alignment with student preferences, future plans, and dreams by choosing those assessments carefully.  For one, the assessments should be ongoing.  Student preferences may change over time and should therefore be revisited year after year.  They should also encourage involvement early on in the student's school career.  Additionally, the assessment should engage multiple stakeholders to ensure all aspects of transition are being addressed.  Finally, assessment results should draw connections between all collected data and produce clear recommendations for the student and their family.  Ensuring that these assessments are age appropriate, culturally relevant, and accessible to both students and families will increase the likelihood of participation by both students and families.  Educating school personnel on the important of transition and transition assessments will encourage their participation as well.

Subject: Greta Durst, Berlin Brothersvalley School District
Body: We can ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MTSGs that are in alignment with their preference by choosing and offering career interest inventories and assessments that will align more with their future goals. Administering interest inventories and assessment when students reach transition age will help to put the puzzle pieces all together to serve as a framework to help the students meet their post secondary goals. Students will grow and change throughout high school, and consistently monitoring their interests and skill levels relative to career goals helps to drive transition planning and are sure all parts are aligned. Students may be in need of targeted support and providing opportunities for interning/employment in the student's chosen careers is a very important part to our already established programs. Finally, inviting students and parents to all IEP meetings and encouraging students and parents to actively participate in transition planning is key to successfully implementing goal aligned transition plans and meeting each child's post secondary goals. This process will be ongoing and always evolving, but it is an excellent place to start and when necessary, we adjust and carry on in the new direction.

Subject: Michelle Murray - Intermediate Unit One (assigned to Jefferson-Morgan School District)
Body:
Each student is a unique individual, therefore when planning transition assessments there should not be a standard assessment. We, as Team Members, need to determine what specifically needs to be assessed and what the selected assessment is assessing and ensure that the answers to these two questions match. We must also ensure that the assessment selected will be comprehensive enough to provided the needed information. We must also determine what decisions can be made off of the results obtained.

In regard to supporting students and parents I believe that one way to accomplish this is to offer to assist with the completion of the assessment. Not in a way that would compromise the assessment validity, but I know many parents who struggle to read the forms provided and/or complete a written response. In the past I have offered to complete survey type assessments in an interview format, where I read all items to the parent and write their response. I also remind students/ parents that there are no right or wrong answers.

Giving students a variety of informal and formal assessments and using results to shape  their transition activities is vital.  They need to know they can change their mind during the year as well.

Parents/ other team members find it helpful when they are provided the information that makes up an assessmt- i.e. not just a score listed but what it means. Other members & parents can complete an informal survey as well

Subject: Olivia Lambert, Brandywine Heights ASD
Body:
When ensuring student's transition assessments results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preference, future plans, and dreams, multiple assessment should be completed periodically throughout the school year, and should include formal and informal methods of assessments based on the student. Interviews should continue to occur with students as they grow and change their preferences. These conversations do not have to occur just once a year, but multiple times depending on the student. 
Engaging parents, families, and school staff in the transition assessment process can occur through a variety of means; connection through IEP meetings, providing checklists and surveys, engaging in community mapping, connecting students to a support network of possible future employees, engaging students through an online career scavenger hunt, career fairs, etc.

We can also provide various different informal and formal assessments to each student to form a better more comprehensive transition plan. By using interviews of students, teachers and parents, we can include them in the process. We can inform families and students of upcoming transition opportunities in the community that may interest them. Subject: Terry Flamm, Brandywine Heights ASD, Rene Reese
Body:
We begin by deciding which assessment/tools we need to use. Interviews with the student need to be completed to determine their interests and future post-secondary goals. This will need to be completed every year since students change, grow, develop differently throughout their high school career. Changes may need to be made if goals have changed for the student.
Discuss these changes with the entire IEP team to keep everyone on the same page. It's important to include multiple disciplinary roles/feedback for the best overall plan.

Subject: Paul Ruhlman, Bedford ASD
Body:
The first assessments in the transition process begin an ongoing refinement of the student's hopes for the future.  Given this change over the course of the student's studies, the assessment should be varied and provide constant information to facilitate refinement.  A student in 8th grade will mostly need different assessments than a 12th grader.  The 8th grader has numerous choices and is in the process of identify larger areas of interest.  Whereas the 11th grader really requires more precise assessments to develop important skills and clear plans for the rapidly approaching future.  In the end, the assessments should provide a variety of information and be individualized to the student.
I believe the student's success depends greatly on the engagement of all members of the IEP team.  If the student doesn't engage in the process, it is virtually impossible to understand their dreams for the future and their perceived needs to reach that dream.  Parent engagement is paramount to the student's success as they will be long-term constant support for the student.  Both students and parents should have lots of opportunities to provide input.  Sometimes this can be simple conversations and other times it may require more formalized approaches to collect the information.  School personnel bring unique training and experiences to the process.  Since they have been through the process numerous times, they can help refine the dream and give insight into the paths available to achieve the student's dream.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Anne Moll/Brandywine Heights/Rene Reese
Body:
First we have to determine what we want to assess and use the correct tool. We must be sure to have conversations with students to see what their interests are and where their passions lie when it comes to post secondary goals. Since students mature as they continue through high school, assessments need to be given each year and discussions with students occur yearly as well. If student post secondary preferences change, the assessments we use may need to change as well.
One way to keep everyone engaged in the transition process is to keep them involved. Have those conversations prior to the IEP meeting.  Get feedback from all parties involved in the meeting and give all participants a chance to speak and share their thoughts and ideas with the team.

To ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences/plans/dreams, a multitude of assessments should be employed. Inventories and surveys are an important part of this process (learning style inventories, living skills inventories, etc.). The assessments should be varied (formal and informal) and periodic (given throughout the school year).

Providing updates/information to students/families regarding transition opportunities is also key.

We can ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams if we first identify what it is we are assessing and if they will provide us with comprehensive information and age appropriate transition planning for instructional purposes. In addition, parents, students, and teachers should be included in completing interviews and reports before transition plans are developed for the student for a comprehensive view.

Body:
To be sure that students' transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams, the assessments should answer the following questions:
1.What is each selected assessment assessing? Is it appropriate for the student's age and level of functioning?
2. Would the assessments provide you with the comprehensive information needed for age appropriate transition planning and instructional purposes?

Assessments should be personalized and frame the transition grid/ annual IEP goals for the student. Subject: Mike Kass - AHCCS
Body:
Assessment results should be aligned to the student's educational aspirations along with their interests. Students at our school started using Xello to help facilitate this process. Xello provides multiple survey assessments that we can use to discuss their plans. We use the results to initiate a conversation about the suggested options. Taking the input from student and parent(s) along with the survey results, we are able to generate a MPSG to anchor the IEP.

One of my goals for my first year in the transition coordinator position is to emphasize the importance of transition planning throughout the building particularly to students with IEPs. I am personally using Xello and creating tasks that address PA career standards to meet the activities and services present in students' transition goals. I have also instructed teachers to promote the resources that we have access to both in the building and outside of it with their caseload parents.

Subject: Sara Bates, Jefferson Morgan School District- LEA

What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams?

By taking a look at informal and formal assessment results and having an open dialogue with the student about those results.  From there we can plan programs/opportunities/goals.

Body:
What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams?

We determine that by knowing where student is, where the student is going and how will they get there.  This happens with the use of transition assessments, along with their overall academic performance and assessments along with their verbalized interest(s).  With that info, CMs, school counselors and others can work with the student to develop and organize and plan their post secondary plans.  
What are some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process?

Parents and other family members can be helpful in guiding student direction.  In that, they can share their observations and informal conversations they have had with the student and shed some light on the child's personal interest.  Together, as a team, the best post-secondary plan can be developed.  As for the "getting" there, school counselors, transition coordinators, information from OVR among others can guide and help to further inform how the student can best achieve their post-secondary goals - "getting" there portion.
Jance~EPASD

Subject: Leigh-Ann Wilson, Philadelphia Electrical and Technology Charter High School
Body:
What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams? What are some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process? 
****************************************
We can ensure that students' transition assessment results produce MTSGs that are in alignment with their preference by continually offering students career interest inventories and informally assessing student skill sets with regard to their post-secondary goals.  Administering interest inventories when students reach transition age are appropriate and engaging to begin the process of creating a solid transition plan.  As students grow throughout high school, consistently monitoring interests and skill sets relative to career goals helps to drive transition planning.  Offering students targeted support and opportunities for interning/employment in chosen careers is integral to our already established Cooperative Program, at PETCHS.  Lastly, inviting students and parents to all IEP meetings and encouraging students and parents to actively participate in transition planning is key to successfully implementing goal aligned transition plans.

Subject: Assessment
Body:
What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams?

Using a variety of assessments will help to ensure that MPSGs are aligned to preferences, future plans and dreams. The specific tool selected should take into consideration the student's age and what part of the process they are in. For example, a junior who has clearly defined career outcomes would not likely be given a preference assessment, but a student turning 14 might be given this type of survey.
What are some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process?

One way to engage all team members is to have open dialog during the IEP meeting to ensure every understands the purpose of both formal and informal assessments. I feel that team members are more likely to contribute to the process if they have an understanding of the "why" and the desired outcome. A variety of viewpoints and perspectives also help to capture all aspects of the students. Each member of the team has valuable information to share including the student.

~Sharon Smith, Hampton Township

Body: It is very important for MPSGs to be aligned to preferences, plans, and dreams. In order to achieve this, members of the student's IEP team (student, parents, services providers) should all participate in collection of informal and formal transition assessments. Student and parent surveys can be used to determine if the student and their families are on the same page for postsecondary goals. These informal surveys can also help point case managers in the right directions for choosing other informal or formal assessments to gain a deeper understanding for the student's future goals and how the school can help the students achieve these goals. Informal and formal assessments should not be a one time thing. Student's interests develop and change over time. It is important for these assessments to be given often. We should not just take what a student and their parents say at the beginning of the 8th grade year to guide all future transition discussions and IEP decisions until the student graduates high school. Informal and formal assessments build upon each other and can be used to guide the team to other assessments in order to narrow the scope on how to best support the student. - Kirsten Kalista

Body: We can ensure that transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are aligned with student preferences, future plans, and dreams by choosing appropriate assessments, i.e., select assessments that focus on areas that are aligned with what a student wants for their future. Assessments should be age appropriate. Choose assessments that will provide information for transition planning and instructional purposes. Choose assessments that focus on specific skills that might be required to meet postsecondary goals. We can include and support students, school personnel, families/parents in the on-going transition assessment process by soliciting their input, including them in surveys/inventories, including them when appropriate in IEP meetings and goal alignment (e.g., a Speech Therapist would be involved in writing a speech/language goal.) Using different types of assessments, both formal and informal will give a broader view of a student’s areas of strength and/or needs/requirements. ~Kat Llewellyn

Body: Using different types of assessment, both informal and formal, and building on prior assessments is needed to help produce MPSGs that are aligned with student plans/dreams.  It's also important to involve the student, family, and school personnel in the assessment process to have a range of information on the student.  The assessments should be varied based on a student's age/grade and goals.  It helps to have an outline of assessments recommended by age/grade, but the assessments should be selected based on the individual student and their transition path - just because a student completed an interest inventory in 8th grade doesn't mean he/she still 'fits' those results a few years later.  Discussing assessments and results as a team helps keep everyone on the same page for on-going transition mapping.  Christine Bosley

Body: To ensure that the MPSG are matching what the student wants for the future, it is important to revisit the topic often. It is necessary to have all stakeholders as part of the conversation and to consider what all members say. Assessments must also be appropriate for the student and the student's preferred outcomes. The age of the student can have an impact on what assessments are provided. Parents and students need resources to help throughout the process. They can benefit from information about the assessments and description of what this process takes place. Families need to feel involved and as though their voices are heard. Students and families need to know that the school is taking the assessment results into consideration and helping to plan goals that match what the student would like to pursue. School personnel need resources to help meet the goals the student. - Nicole Clemens

Body: Results of both formal and informal transition assessments need to be documented within the present levels section of the student's IEP. Daily classroom instruction should include exposure to varied workplace scenarios, training, on the job expectations, and behavior, etc. so that students can make a well informed decision when asked their preferences for postsecondary planning.  Results of student assessments need to be shared with parents so that all involved are on the same page. Materials relating to Transition planning need to be shared with parents in order to help them better assist and guide their student during this process. - Vicki Kulp

Body:
Look at the age and grade level of the student. A 9th graders transition assessments should be different than an 11th graders transition assessments. Transition assessments should happen periodically throughout the school year, not just right before the student’s IEP/RR is due. Completing transition assessments throughout the school helps identify any changes in the student’s preferences, future plans, dreams, etc. 


When choosing the transition assessments, reference the following 3 questions: 1. What are the assessments assessing? 2. Would the assessments provide information needed for transition planning and instructional purposes? Would the assessments provide you with comprehension information needed for age appropriate transition planning and instructional purposes? 3. What decision could you make for your students with the completed and analyzed assessment information? Are results valued? Referencing the questions when choosing transition assessments will help increase the chances of producing MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and their dreams. 
Monthly check-ins with the students, the students; families, and the students’ parents about student’s progress in relation to the student’s transition goals 


Provide resources (websites, agencies, seminar, lectures, presentations, workshops, etc) to assist with the transition goals/process
Nicole Nasatka - ASD

Body: It is important to ensure that the transition assessment process is ongoing.  As members of a student’s IEP team, we should expect that student interests and goals for themselves are going to change over time.  By using varied formal and informal transition assessments throughout the year, we are able to gather information to support students in developing a plan to achieve their goals.  It is also important to include families in the transition assessment process through surveys and interviews.  The results of transition assessments should be communicated with all members of the IEP team so that as a team, we can consistently support the needs of the student.     – Katelyn Emory

Rachael Davis; BASD 


What are some ways we can ensure that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams? 
A variety of assessments should be utilized to address transition needs. Interest inventories, independent living skills inventories, ONET profilers, learning styles, and more. This will help students and their parents to truly understand where their child is at and the steps needed to acquire their goals. 
 
What are some ways we can include and support students, parents/family members, school personnel engagement in the transition assessment on-going process? 
  Student and parent transition surveys/checklists must be used to gather data each year. Involve students and parents in quarterly meetings with service providers. Provide flyers/information to families regarding transition opportunities.

Body: Some ways that we can ensure  that students’ transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans and dreams are through formal and informal ongoing transitioning assessments. This includes conversations and meetings with the student and family to help to write goals that assist with the development of independence. Surveys and interest profiles can be used to gather information about interests, vocational interests, and preferences. Measures can include learning characteristics, critical thinking skills. At our school we hold career/college fairs and speak with students and families about options this involves the community and connects the school environment. Our career and college center shares information with the school and invites students to come in for free workshops and assessments.  Surveys are also sent home to families to share observations, concerns, goals and any other information relevant to transition. Having a variety of ways to engage and assess hopefully helps to produces MPSGs that align with student preferences and dreams.--- Maisha Utterbach, ASD, Allentown, PA.

Body: Danielle Sommers- To ensure alignment of preferences, we should check for consistency across assessments whether formal or informal. For example, if a student indicate on one assessment that they enjoy working outside but on another assessment the student indicates that he has no outdoor working skills, we would need to get some clarification on that particular item. Also, simply asking the student what they think about whether the MPSGs fit in to their goals and interests goes a long way to ensuring student investment in the transition process. As long as the student is able to communicate, he/she should be able to indicate whether these goals line up with their own. We can support students by checking in regularly with how they are doing in classes or activities related to their areas of interest.  It is also helpful to provide a list of resources to families that will allow the student to explore their interests outside of the daily school setting.  For example, if a student expresses interest in working with animals as a career, perhaps knowing local shelters that need volunteers would give students an opportunity to explore that particular interest.

It is also important for these assessments to be ongoing, especially because students may change their mind about their goals as they move through high school and learn more about themselves and different careers. In addition, having a variety of assessments and an ongoing dialogue with families allow for adjustment of goals as needed.

Body: We need to be sure to choose appropriate assessments.  As discussed in the module, interest inventories are usually better suited for underclassmen, while more targeted assessments are appropriate for upperclassmen.  The transition assessment should also be tailored to the specific needs of the student.  Some students may require assessments that are more tailored to functional needs, while others may not have as many needs in that area.  In all cases, assessments must be given in which the student's voice is clearly heard.  By regularly touching base with students and families and being aware of the student's and family's hopes and dreams for the future, as well as periodically checking to see of those desires have changed, we can be sure to keep the entire team engaged in the process.  Jennifer Moody

Body: In order to ensure that transition assessment results produce MPSGs that are in alignment with a student's preferences, plans, and dreams, we need to use a variety of assessments- both formal and informal.  These assessments should be ongoing, not just once a year prior to the IEP meeting, and should give increasing more focused information as the student plans their life post-high school.  Parent/family involvement is also helpful, because they also know their student well and will have helpful insights.  I think the importance of these different assessments, as well as the long-term goal of preparation for/success in life after high school should be shared repeatedly with both the student and the family to encourage their participation.  Hopefully the variety of the assessments as well as the bigger picture taking shape will also be motivating and exciting. -- Amanda Caton

Jeff Pelly, IU17

In terms of ensuring that students' Transition assessment results produce measurable post secondary goals that are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams I feel we must make sure the assessment we provide the student is appropriate.  Many LEAs have Transition scope and sequence documents that outline what assessment will be given in 7th grade, 8th grade, etc.  This may be applicable for some, but for other students (who may have more cognitive delays, etc), the assessment must be appropriate so the outcome is warranted.  Furthermore, I feel that by involving aspects of information collected through PA 339 and ESSA, these artifacts may help with a students' overall Transition planning.  Finally, involving the student, family members, District personnel, and Community Agency representatives during Transition Staffing Meetings is a great way to continue this engagement process - making sure Transition is always ongoing.

Body: When monitoring, the question related to assessment which must be answered is "289.  [Is there]  Evidence that the measurable postsecondary goal(s) were based on age appropriate transition assessment (locate assessment information in the student’s ER, RR, and/or IEP Present Levels (section II of the IEP)) " The trick here ifor monitoring reviewers s to determine if the assessment info is age appropriate. Informal assessments are even more difficult to consider, if they do not have titles, are not leveled for age, are not replicable, and do not yield orderly information.  When I see a combination of informal assessment information and formal assessment information, especially in the context of a sequence of year upon year information articulated in the Present Levels of the IEP, or in the ER/RR,  I  feel much more confident that I can mark this item "Yes, in compliance". Debbie Sotack
